ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learn to read state-of-the-art research papers, discuss them in class through presentations, and apply my new research techniques to cool, real projects.
I learned a lot about machine learning and the important papers contributing to computer graphics research

This course is only useful if you would like to be informed in current and relevant papers in the field of computer graphics. Each class consists solely of student presentations on papers related to the course theme, in our case this was neural networks. Having taken no prior classes in machine learning or computer graphics (this course lists no prerequisites) I was completely beyond my depth in terms of understanding any of the math or code of any of the papers we talked about in class. That said, I did take away a broad understanding of which areas and topics are relevant to computer graphics researchers working with neural networks today.
I learned the state-of-art research topics in computer graphics and learned some basic skills of using machine learning framework to train neural network models.
I developed my paper reading and analysis skills through the extensive number of papers I read.

Get a more detailed understanding of sub-domains in computer graphics which I am not familiar before.
Improve my presentation skills where I learn to present my contents in a more organized and audience-friendly way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was extremely poorly organized. There was very little learning since student presented on articles that we were required to write responses to prior to the presentation. Additionally, there were no other assignments besides the reading responses/presentations until we got to the final project. It was very difficult coming up with and executing a full coding project after not learning how to actually implement anything in AI for computer graphics during the semester.

The teaching style is good  the number of presentations helps to keep students engaged throughout the semester. The comments from Prof. Dorsey on certain papers are often the most valuable, as they give insight into industry and research from someone who has a huge amount of experience.
I really liked the presentation projects

This is not a good course. I can imagine that, for those already set on going to grad school in the particular area of graphics, that it's helpfulit lets you review relevant literature and practice your paper-reading and presentation skills. Otherwise, it's not worth iteven if you are interested in separate subfields of computer graphics or computer science.

Beware that there is no "teaching" in this course: beyond the first lecture, there was no lecturethe only class time consisted of student presentations and guest lectures. It was clear that the only students able to follow the presentations were those with prior background in the field, aka mostly masters and PHD candidates. I would love if professor Dorsey devoted at least half of the class time to breaking down some of the papers and learning about the most useful and relevant techniques, instead of having us present on them without much explanation. It would also be great if a machine learning course was listed as a prerequisite for this class, as it is clearly necessary to understand how neural networks work before taking it.
Students engage in the paper reading and discussion actively. Students develop various interesting course projects and learn a lot from each other.
I feel like there should be more instructor engagement in the course as most class sessions consisted almost entirely of students speaking.

Strengths:
Students have chances to get fully envolved in class discussion and presentation.
The workload is fair and helpful for students to learn solid knowledge.

Weaknesses:
The feedbacks on homeworks are not enough.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course unless you have prior experience with AI and computer graphics. This course is much more designed for graduate students. It was very frustrating having to create a project without any guidance or feedback.

Yes, this is a fantastic class to learn to read research papers, which is a very valuable skill even if you don't intend to go into research. It allows you to learn about the most modern techniques in your field. The topic of this class changes every year and is always cool, modern, and exciting.
Yes

Nounless you are already doing research in the field of computer graphics and have a strong grasp of neural networks and computer graphics, and are willing to build an entire project from scratch with next to no guidance or project guidelines.
Of course! This course introduces the state-of-art research topics in computer graphics and it is a good course if someone would like to learn about graphics.
It's an okay introductory course but it didn't cover state of the art methods as much as I would like

Yes, especially to those who want to get an insight into computer graphics and vision research. This course is organized in the form that requires student to present their own understandings of papers in graphics. The preliminary of presenting the papers in an organized way is to fully understand the paper, therefore students can learn a lot from doing these presentations.
